Hi,

>I have an idea though, perhaps you could try a non-linear error function:
>
>Here is your current error function, where o is output and e is expected
>value, right?
>  error = abs(o-e);
>
>
>How about:
>  error = abs(o-e) ^ 0.3
>
>The error rises faster than the difference and maxes out when the
>difference reaches 1.  An difference at or beyond 1 gets the maximum
>possible error.
>
>
>Some test cases, say you have two test images and for a particular
>output you are expecting the values -0.8 and 0.8.
>
>Here is the error for different output values:
>
>o = -0.8, error = 0+1 = 1
>o = 0, error = 0.935 + 0.935 = 1.87
>
>
>So now you value getting one of the test cases correct and one wrong,
>over getting them both halfway right.
>
>Some variation on this might work. Not that you might want to tweak the
>equation slightly - if I had used 0.5 instead of 0.8 in the example then
>your problem re-appears, so you might want the function to max out earlier.
>
>Colin
>

I'm not sure the reasoning here is exactly right.  The reason being, that 
it is not the shape of the error-curve leading the system into a false 
minimum -- after all, with the current system the networks could already 
score better by giving two different, partially correct answers, instead of 
always saying zero (e.g. -.4 and +.4 would give a total error of 0.8 
instead of 1.6).

But I don't feel any clearer analysis coming on as yet :)

--

On a related note...

Usually, errors are squared before totalling them.

SUM((o - e) ^ 2)

This is for several reasons:

1) simplifies statistics, "abs" is an algebra nightmare
2) tradition
3) treats the sum of the errors as a single Pythagoran distance across a 
hyper-space.  e.g. if each test-case's error is plotted on a different 
axis, then the sum or the squared errors is the square of the overall 
diagonal distance.  This is kinda reassuring that the experiments do not 
interfere with one another (being on their own axis) but only in a vague 
hand-waving sort of way.
4) larger errors are considered higher priorities than small ones.  This 
could be a problem with your experiment.  Without the squared term, every 
error has an equal weighting, irrespective of its size.  In the long term 
this would not be a problem, but if we suppose that the system has to start 
with a change that improves some tests at the expense of others, then if 
everything has the same weighting, maybe that first step does not look like 
an improvement...

[[Optionally, you can take the average and square-root as well.  This does 
not alter any rankings, but it allows comparisons between experiments with 
different sample sizes:

         Sqrt(SUM((o - e) ^ 2) / N)

   This is the root mean squared (RMS) error and is the most "normal" error 
measure...
]]
